content.description:
Powerful and committing for the grade, Tang follows a series of long moves between good crimps up the middle of the steep wall. Get ready for the cruxy topout.

A great climb that I felt was marred only by the fact that the crimps were kind of sharp. Even so, I thought this was a great v5.
content.protection: At least 2 pads and a spotter would help make this much safer. It did not feel super smart to do this alone.
content.location: Left side of the Tang boulder, maybe 2 meters right of the v7 arete problem. Start sitting with a nice rail/crimp thing.

content.description: Great easy route that follows some pockets and flakes up the back of the Gatorade Boulder.  This may already be a climb, but just wanted to put it up here.  If it is just message me the details, and I will change it.
content.location: On the gatorade boulder, go to the backside. It starts on the corner in a really good pocket, and follows flakes the whole way up veering right.

content.description: This problem is on the face, just left around the corner from Gatorade. Stand start with bad feet, right hand on a slopey side pull crimp, left hand on a good side pull crimp. Slap up to a slanting rail and then to the top.

Powerade follows fairly positive rails that don't quite point the right way, and requires a couple of technical foot placements to make it feel like v3.

Would be a much better problem, because the rock is great, and the moves are fun, but it has a boulder on the left of the start that both makes the opening moves a little awkward, and also gives it a worse landing. All the same, worth doing if you are in the area.
content.location: Right side of the Gatorade boulder, start standing to the right of the rock at the base of the face.

content.description: Start matched in the undercling edge. A hard left hand cross to a small crimp gets you started. The first few moves are the hardest, then keep it together for the top-out.
content.location: Pretty much smack in the center of the boulder

content.description: Start in a low right hand pocket and left hand hueco jug. Climb right on side pulls to a big move to slopers at the lip. Straight up are two crimps, a slopey jug, and a high top-out.
content.location: The right-most problem on the boulder.

content.description: Climb the thin face on holds that don't quite face in the direction you want them to. The tenuous and technical quality of this vertical climb is what gives it its charm. I don't generally like vertical climbs very much, but I thought this was well worth the effort.
content.location: On the Gatorade boulder, about 20 feet up canyon from the Tang boulder. Look for the pockety, crimpy face with beautiful orange rock.
